title: 103_hr2307
content: The Act is titled the "Workers' Political Rights Act" and includes limitations on contributions and expenditures by labor organizations. The "Workers' Political Rights Act" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to include requirements for labor organizations regarding political activities. Labor organizations must provide written notification to employees regarding their right not to pay for political activities through union dues. The "Workers' Political Rights Act" requires labor organizations to inform employees of their right to opt out of funding political activities through union dues. Employees cannot be compelled to join a labor organization, but can choose to pay an agency fee instead. The agency fee is limited to the cost of exclusive representation services. Full members who pay dues are entitled to additional benefits. The labor organization must provide a reduction in membership dues for employees who opt out of funding political activities. The organization's spending on political activities and exclusive representation services must be calculated based on the previous fiscal year. Employees must receive an annual financial examination by an independent accountant to ensure compliance. The labor organization must provide a reduction in membership dues for employees who opt out of funding political activities. An independent accountant must conduct an annual financial examination to verify the organization's spending on political activities and exclusive representation services. The organization must also maintain procedures to determine costs chargeable to agency fee payors and provide a process for challenging these costs. The labor organization must finance certain expenditures only with funds legally collected for its separate segregated fund. This applies to communications advocating for or against a specific candidate for public office. The amendments made by section 2 of the Act apply to contributions and expenditures made after the enactment date.
